comments:
This course provides an introduction to the theory, the methods, and the concerns of corporate finance. The concepts developed in FNCE 100 form the foundation for all elective finance courses. The main topics include: 1) the time value of money and capital budgeting techniques; 2) uncertainty and the trade-off between risk and return; 3) security market efficiency; 4) optimal capital structure, and 5) dividend policy decisions.

Students, for the most part, felt that this course is “useful and practical,” especially for students planning to concentrate in finance. However, some would have liked to see “more tie-ins with the current economy and financial situation.” Students also felt that they learned a lot from the course, but some of the readings were not very useful.

According to students, Professor Kiku was very “knowledgeable and did a great job in communicating the subject matter.” However, they found her “too strict, intimidating and condescending at times.” While help outside of class was available, some were disappointed, believing that it was insufficient and lacked accessibility.

Students thought that this course was challenging but fairly graded. Exams were “hard and tricky” but some felt that served as a motivation to study harder. The workload is heavy in this course, including constant practice problems.
